metadata.titleEn: HiTIC-Monthly: a monthly high spatial resolution (1 km) human thermal index collection over China during 2003–2020
metadata.description:
The monthly High spatial resolution human Thermal Index Collection (HiTIC-Monthly) includes near-surface air temperature (SAT) and 11 commonly used human-perceived temperature indices: indoor Apparent Temperature (ATin), outdoor shaded Apparent Temperature (ATout), Discomfort Index (DI), Effective Temperature (ET), Heat Index (HI), Humidex (HMI), Modified Discomfort Index (MDI), Net Effective Temperature (NET), simplified Wet Bulb Globe Temperature (sWBGT), Wet-Bulb Temperature (WBT), and Wind Chill Temperature (WCT). This dataset has a high spatial resolution of 1 km × 1 km and covers mainland China from January 2003 to December 2020. The overall R-square, root mean square error, and mean absolute error of the 12 thermal indices in the HiTIC dataset are 0.996, 0.693°C, and 0.512°C, respectively. It is compressed or stacked by year, and each zip package or stack is composed of 12 monthly images in the GeoTIFF or NetCDF format. The unit of the dataset is 0.01 degree Celsius (°C), and the values are stored in an integer type (Int16) for saving storage space, and need to be divided by 100 to get the values in degree Celcius when in use. The projection coordinate system of the dataset is Albers Equal Area Conic Projection. The naming rule and other detailed information can be found in “README.pdf”. 

If you have any questions when using the HiTIC-Monthly dataset, please feel free to contact Miss Hui Zhang via zhangh573@mail2.sysu.edu.cn, Dr. Ming Luo via luom38@mail.sysu.edu.cn, or Dr. Yongquan Zhao via zhaoyq66@mail.sysu.edu.cn. More details on the procedure of producing the HiTIC-Monthly dataset and its accuracy assessment can be found in: Zhang, H., Luo, M., Zhao, Y., Lin, L., Ge, E., Yang, Y., Ning, G., Cong, J., Zeng, Z., Gui, K., Li, J., Chan, T. O., Li, X., Wu, S., Wang, P., and Wang, X.(2023).HiTIC-Monthly: a monthly high spatial resolution (1 km) human thermal index collection over China during 2003–2020, Earth Syst. Sci. Data, 15, 359–381, https://doi.org/10.5194/essd-15-359-2023, 2023.
metadata.instructions: The dataset is stored in GeoTIFF or NetCDF format. The file name is "HiTIC_Monthly_China_{Index}_{year}01_{year}12.nc" where Index refers to human thermal index (e.g., WBT, HI), and year means calendar year.

background: Human-perceived thermal comfort (known as human-perceived temperature) measures the combined effects of multiple meteorological factors (e.g., temperature, humidity, and wind speed) and can be aggravated under the influences of global warming and local human activities. With the most rapid urbanization and the largest population, China is being severely threatened by aggravating human thermal stress. Global climate change has brought significant challenges to human society and natural systems by inducing higher air temperature and more frequent extreme weather and climate events around the world.
research objective: Here, we generated the first high spatial resolution (1 km) dataset of monthly human thermal index collection (HiTIC-Monthly) over China during 2003–2020.
challenges: However, the variations of thermal stress in China at a fine scale have not been fully understood. This gap is mainly due to the lack of a high-resolution gridded dataset of human thermal indices.
methods: In this collection, 12 commonly used thermal indices were generated by the Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LightGBM) learning algorithm from multi-source data, including land surface temperature, topography, land cover, population density, and impervious surface fraction. Their accuracies were comprehensively assessed based on the observations at 2419 weather stations across the mainland of China.
dataset: Here, we generated the first high spatial resolution (1 km) dataset of monthly human thermal index collection (HiTIC-Monthly) over China during 2003–2020. In this collection, 12 commonly used thermal indices were generated by the Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LightGBM) learning algorithm from multi-source data, including land surface temperature, topography, land cover, population density, and impervious surface fraction. Their accuracies were comprehensively assessed based on the observations at 2419 weather stations across the mainland of China.
findings: The results show that our dataset has desirable accuracies, with the mean R2, root mean square error, and mean absolute error of 0.996, 0.693 ◦C, and 0.512 ◦C, respectively, by averaging the 12 indices. Moreover, the data exhibit high agreements with the observations across spatial and temporal dimensions, demonstrating the broad applicability of our dataset. A comparison with two existing datasets also suggests that our high-resolution dataset can describe a more explicit spatial distribution of the thermal information, showing great potentials in fine-scale (e.g., intra-urban) studies. Further investigation reveals that nearly all thermal indices exhibit increasing trends in most parts of China during 2003–2020. The increase is especially significant in North China, Southwest China, the Tibetan Plateau, and parts of Northwest China, during spring and summer.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'human-perceived thermal comfort' in the context of meteorological studies?
Definition.Answer: Human-perceived thermal comfort, also known as human-perceived temperature, measures the combined effects of multiple meteorological factors such as temperature, humidity, and wind speed. It can be influenced by global warming and local human activities, posing challenges to human society and natural systems.

Definition.Question: How is 'high spatial resolution' defined in the context of environmental datasets?
Definition.Answer: High spatial resolution in environmental datasets refers to the granularity of data, which in this context is a 1 km grid size. This allows for detailed mapping and analysis of environmental variables and indices across geographic areas.

Definition.Question: What does 'Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LightGBM) learning algorithm' refer to in data processing?
Definition.Answer: The Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LightGBM) learning algorithm is a method used for generating datasets from multi-source data. It is utilized for creating high-resolution gridded datasets of human thermal indices by integrating various data sources such as land surface temperature, topography, land cover, population density, and impervious surface fraction.

Comparison.Question: How does the application of the Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LightGBM) learning algorithm in generating human thermal indices compare to traditional statistical methods in terms of accuracy and data integration?
Comparison.Answer: The LightGBM learning algorithm was used to generate 12 thermal indices from multi-source data, achieving high accuracy with mean R2, root mean square error, and mean absolute error of 0.996, 0.693°C, and 0.512°C, respectively. This indicates a high level of accuracy and effective integration of diverse data sources compared to what might be expected from traditional statistical methods.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the spatial and temporal resolutions of high-resolution datasets impact the understanding of human thermal stress compared to lower-resolution datasets?
Comparison.Answer: High-resolution datasets, such as the one with 1 km spatial resolution, provide a more explicit spatial distribution of thermal information and demonstrate high agreement with observations across spatial and temporal dimensions. This enables a finer-scale understanding of human thermal stress, as opposed to the broader, less detailed insights provided by lower-resolution datasets.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data collection methodologies for assessing human-perceived thermal comfort when using weather station observations versus machine learning algorithms like LightGBM?
Comparison.Answer: Weather station observations provide direct measurements of meteorological factors, whereas the LightGBM algorithm integrates multi-source data, such as land surface temperature and population density, to estimate human thermal indices. The algorithm-based approach allows for the generation of a comprehensive dataset over large areas with high spatial resolution, which might not be feasible using solely weather station data.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the effectiveness of the Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LightGBM) algorithm in generating high-resolution thermal indices from multi-source data?
Interpretation.Answer: The Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LightGBM) algorithm has been effective in generating high-resolution thermal indices, as indicated by the high accuracy of the dataset. The mean R2, root mean square error, and mean absolute error of 0.996, 0.693°C, and 0.512°C, respectively, suggest that the algorithm accurately captures the variations in thermal indices when trained on multi-source data including land surface temperature, topography, land cover, population density, and impervious surface fraction.

Interpretation.Question: How do variations in spatial and temporal dimensions of human thermal indices reveal patterns in thermal stress across China?
Interpretation.Answer: The dataset reveals that nearly all thermal indices exhibit increasing trends in most parts of China during 2003–2020. The increase is notably significant in North China, Southwest China, the Tibetan Plateau, and parts of Northwest China during spring and summer, indicating that these areas are experiencing heightened thermal stress over time. The broad applicability of the dataset across spatial and temporal dimensions also shows high agreement with observed data, allowing for detailed examination of thermal stress patterns.

Interpretation.Question: What underlying data patterns can be interpreted from the comparison of high-resolution thermal index datasets with existing datasets?
Interpretation.Answer: The high-resolution dataset demonstrates a more explicit spatial distribution of thermal information compared to existing datasets. This suggests that the dataset can provide finer detail in spatial patterns, which is particularly beneficial for intra-urban studies. Such fine-scale data allows for better understanding and management of localized thermal stress, potentially leading to improved urban planning and climate adaptation strategies.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the need for high-resolution gridded datasets of human thermal indices in China?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The variations of thermal stress in China at a fine scale have not been fully understood, primarily due to the lack of a high-resolution gridded dataset of human thermal indices. This gap raises the need for such datasets to better comprehend these variations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the increasing trends in thermal indices across most parts of China during 2003–2020?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Nearly all thermal indices exhibit increasing trends in most parts of China during 2003–2020, which are particularly significant in regions such as North China, Southwest China, the Tibetan Plateau, and parts of Northwest China during spring and summer. This increase is likely due to the influences of global warming and local human activities.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using the Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LightGBM) learning algorithm for generating human thermal indices from multi-source data?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using the LightGBM algorithm can result in high accuracy in generating human thermal indices, as evidenced by the mean R2, root mean square error, and mean absolute error of 0.996, 0.693°C, and 0.512°C, respectively. It also allows for comprehensive assessments based on observations across a large number of weather stations, demonstrating broad applicability and the ability to describe explicit spatial distributions of thermal information.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the inclusion of multiple data sources, such as land surface temperature and population density, affect the development of a high-resolution human thermal index dataset?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Incorporating multiple data sources, such as land surface temperature, topography, land cover, population density, and impervious surface fraction, results in a comprehensive dataset that captures the variations in human thermal stress with high spatial resolution. This approach contributes to the dataset's desirable accuracies and its ability to reflect explicit spatial distributions that are crucial for understanding fine-scale thermal stress changes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What objectives drive the creation of a high spatial resolution dataset of human thermal indices for China?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to provide a fine-scale understanding of thermal stress variations across China, addressing the gap due to the lack of high-resolution gridded datasets, and to assess thermal stress under the influences of global warming and urbanization.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to utilize a machine learning algorithm like LightGBM in the generation of human thermal indices?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Using LightGBM allows for the integration of multi-source data such as land surface temperature, topography, land cover, population density, and impervious surface fraction, enabling the creation of accurate and comprehensive human thermal indices with high spatial resolution.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the intentions behind assessing the accuracy of thermal indices based on observations from a large number of weather stations?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intention is to comprehensively validate the dataset's accuracy and ensure its reliability and applicability across various spatial and temporal dimensions, providing insights into thermal stress trends and supporting fine-scale studies.

These data are processed and modeled to produce thermal indices at a fine spatial resolution.

Request/Directive.Question: Please examine the methodologies used for generating high spatial resolution human thermal indices using machine learning algorithms and evaluate their effectiveness.
Request/Directive.Answer: The methodologies for generating high spatial resolution human thermal indices involve using the Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LightGBM) learning algorithm. This method utilizes multi-source data, including land surface temperature, topography, land cover, population density, and impervious surface fraction. The effectiveness of these methodologies was evaluated based on observations from 2419 weather stations across mainland China, resulting in high accuracy with mean R2, root mean square error, and mean absolute error of 0.996, 0.693°C, and 0.512°C, respectively.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the challenges faced in understanding fine-scale variations of thermal stress and suggest potential data collection techniques to address these challenges.

Utilizing advanced machine learning algorithms like LightGBM can further enhance the resolution and accuracy of the dataset.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze how the spatial and temporal accuracies of human thermal index datasets can be assessed and suggest improvements for future data collections.
Request/Directive.Answer: The spatial and temporal accuracies of human thermal index datasets can be assessed by comparing the dataset with observations from a wide network of weather stations, such as the 2419 stations used in mainland China. The dataset's high agreements across spatial and temporal dimensions demonstrate its applicability. Improvements for future data collections could include increasing the density of weather stations for validation, incorporating additional environmental variables, and using more sophisticated machine learning models to capture complex interactions and variations in thermal indices.
